diagnoses: Drug reactions (e.g., drug rash with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms [DRESS] syndrome)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Vitamin B Deficiencies (e.g., B2, B6, B12)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Viral infections (e.g., COVID-19, depending on the time and context)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with arthropathy, leukopenia, fever, and can lead to inflammation of various organs including the joints (synovitis) and the heart (acute pericarditis).

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune disorder characterized by chronic inflammation of the joints (arthropathy and synovitis), which can occasionally be associated with systemic features like fever and, rarely, pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Reactive Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: This condition, which can follow certain infections, presents with joint pain (arthropathy, synovitis), and can also feature other systemic symptoms such as fever; pericarditis and leukopenia are less commonly associated.

diagnoses.name: Adult Onset Still's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: A rare type of inflammatory arthritis characterized by a triad of fever, arthralgia, and a salmon-pink rash. Leukopenia is less common, but acute pericarditis and synovitis can occur.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: A multisystem inflammatory disease that can present with arthropathy, fever, leukopenia due to bone marrow involvement, and less frequently, acute pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily affecting the heart valves, it can present with fever, arthralgias or arthropathy, and leukopenia. Acute pericarditis is a rare complication.

diagnoses.name: Viral Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Certain viral infections can lead to transient or acute arthritis (arthropathy and synovitis), fever, and leukopenia. Rarely, viruses can also cause acute pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: An inflammatory joint disease associated with psoriasis, which can have overlapping symptoms including arthropathy, synovitis, and in some individuals, systemic features like fever. Acute pericarditis and leukopenia are less commonly associated.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This disease features signs and symptoms of a combination of disorders including lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, involving arthropathy, acute pericarditis, fever, and potentially leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Caused by Borrelia burgdorferi, this tick-borne illness can lead to arthropathy, acute pericarditis in late stages, fever, and occasionally leukopenia.

diagnoses: Lupus Nephritis specifically (as part of SLE)
Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
Hemorrhagic fever (such as Hantavirus, Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever)
Rickettsial diseases (e.g., Rocky Mountain spotted fever)
Schizophrenia (in the context of autoimmune encephalitis)

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: Diabetes can cause hyperglycemia, and neuropathy associated with diabetes might manifest as hearing loss. Diabetes might also indirectly cause headaches through glucose level fluctuations.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Diseases
diagnoses.reasoning: Certain autoimmune diseases can cause a wide variety of symptoms including hyperglycemia, lymphadenitis, and potentially hearing loss due to nerve involvement.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Lyme disease can cause lymphadenitis and might contribute to neurological symptoms like obsessive-compulsive behavior. It can occasionally cause headaches and hearing loss due to nerve inflammation.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.reasoning: HIV can cause lymphadenitis (one of the earliest signs), and as the virus progresses, it can lead to nervous system involvement that might manifest as obsessive-compulsive behaviors. Headaches are also a common symptom.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.reasoning: Neurosyphilis can cause headaches and hearing loss. Syphilis can also cause lymphadenitis in its secondary stage.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.reasoning: Though primarily linked to low metabolism, it can occasionally present with symptoms like hearing loss. It could also have psychiatric manifestations such as obsessive-compulsive behavior.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.reasoning: Meningitis, an inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, mainly causes headache and can lead to hearing loss. Obsessive-compulsive behavior might occur in neurological sequelae.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.reasoning: This inflammation of the blood vessels can sometimes cause headaches and hyperglycemia due to steroid treatment, and hearing loss through damage to auditory nerves or structures.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reasoning: This inflammatory disease can cause lymphadenitis and has been associated with hyperglycemia as well as hearing loss due to granulomas affecting the nervous system.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.reasoning: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is known for its widespread effects on the body, including the potential for causing headaches, hearing loss (through nerve damage), and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to make too many red blood cells, which thickens the blood and slows its flow.

diagnoses.name: Iron deficiency anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition marked by a deficiency of red blood cells or hemoglobin in the blood, leading to fatigue and weakness. It can be related to or cause symptoms like dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Stress-induced cardiomyopathy (Takotsubo cardiomyopathy)
diagnoses.description: A temporary heart condition that is often preceded by intense physical or emotional stress, mimicking a heart attack, but without blocked coronary arteries.

diagnoses.name: Oral leukoplakia
diagnoses.description: A condition where thick, white patches form on the gums, the inside of the cheeks, and the bottom of the mouth. It can be a precursor to cancer.

diagnoses.name: Hypereosinophilic syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a persistently elevated level of eosinophils (a type of white blood cell) in the blood for at least six months without an obvious cause, leading to damage to multiple organs including the skin, which may cause migratory pruritus.

diagnoses.name: Cholestasis
diagnoses.description: A condition where bile flow is reduced or stopped, leading to itching (pruritus). It can be part of liver diseases and may also cause dysgeusia due to the buildup of bile acids in the body.

diagnoses.name: Hepatitis C
diagnoses.description: A viral infection that causes liver inflammation, sometimes leading to serious liver damage. It can cause symptoms such as dysgeusia and leukoplakia.

diagnoses.name: Multiple myeloma
diagnoses.description: A cancer of plasma cells, a type of white blood cell in bone marrow. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including an increase in blood viscosity (similar to polycythemia) and potential oral manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Lichen planus
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory condition that affects the skin and mucous membranes inside the mouth, which may present as leukoplakia and can cause itching (pruritus).

diagnoses.name: Diabetes mellitus
diagnoses.description: A metabolic disorder characterized by high blood sugar, which can lead to a variety of symptoms, including dysgeusia and potentially contributing to conditions such as polycythemia and leukoplakia.

diagnoses: Vitamin deficiency (e.g., Vitamin D, Vitamin B12)
Constitutional delay of growth and puberty

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. It's characterized by symptoms like fatigue, joint pain, skin rashes, and fevers. Lupus can lead to both hypersensitivity reactions and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing inflammation in the blood vessels. This condition can lead to multiple symptoms including painful mouth sores, genital sores, inflammation in parts of the eye, and various skin rashes.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth. Sjögren's Syndrome can also cause joint pain, skin rashes, and chronic fatigue, reflecting systemic involvement.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that involve inflammation in blood vessels, which can cause aneurysms. Symptoms also often include fatigue, weight loss, and muscle pains.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, primarily the lungs and lymph glands. Symptoms include tiredness, swollen lymph nodes, and eye inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Giant Cell Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease affecting the blood vessels of the scalp, neck, and arms. It can cause headaches, scalp tenderness, jaw pain, vision problems, and symptoms related to inflammation like fatigue and fever.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder that causes inflammation of the arteries in your body. This can lead to damage in the tissues and organs. Symptoms might include fatigue, weight loss, and muscle and joint pain.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms are varied and can include fatigue, depression, and pain.

diagnoses.name: Churg-Strauss Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Also known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, it's a disorder marked by inflammation of blood vessels. Symptoms may include asthma, sinusitis, and skin changes.

diagnoses.name: Depressive Disorder
diagnoses.description: While primarily a psychiatric condition, depression can be associated with a wide range of physical symptoms, including fatigue, pain, and in some cases, physical manifestations like weight changes.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.reason: Common cause of infertility; may also contribute to obesity and can lead to sleep apnea.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.reason: Directly listed; can lead to infertility and has been associated with increased risk of miscarriage.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reason: Can cause urinary tract infections due to high blood sugars; can also lead to obesity, contributing to sleep apnea.

diagnoses.name: Obesity
diagnoses.reason: Can worsen or lead to obstructive sleep apnea; also associated with infertility and miscarriage risk.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.reason: While not directly linked, anemia can result from heavy menstrual cycles associated with miscarriages or PCOS.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.reason: Recurrent urinary tract infections may lead to or indicate existing kidney issues; already complicated by hypertension can contribute to sleep apnea.

diagnoses.name: Hyperprolactinemia
diagnoses.reason: Elevated prolactin levels can cause infertility; hypothyroidism can increase prolactin levels.

diagnoses.name: Endometriosis
diagnoses.reason: Can cause infertility; some studies suggest a possible link to miscarriage.

diagnoses.name: Uterine Fibroids
diagnoses.reason: Can cause miscarriages and lead to infertility, depending on their size and location.

diagnoses.name: Urinary Tract Infections
diagnoses.reason: Directly listed; recurrent UTIs may indicate or contribute to other underlying health issues.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Menstrual disorders (e.g., menorrhagia as a primary condition)
Hypertension (high blood pressure) / Hypotension (low blood pressure)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis)

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Strokes may cause sudden weakness, paralysis of the face, arm, or leg, and difficulty speaking or understanding speech.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). It attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers and causes communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body. Symptoms include weakness, numbness, and in some cases dysphagia.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: Myasthenia gravis is characterized by weakness and rapid fatigue of any of the muscles under your voluntary control. It's caused by a breakdown in the normal communication between nerves and muscles. There's no cure for myasthenia gravis, but treatment can help relieve signs and symptoms, such as weakness of arm or leg muscles, double vision, drooping eyelids, and difficulties with speech, chewing, swallowing and breathing.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Brain tumors can cause a wide range of symptoms including weakness, trouble with speech, and swallowing difficulties. Symptoms often depend on the tumor's size, location, and rate of growth.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: ALS, also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, is a progressive neurodegenerative disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and the spinal cord. It causes muscle weakness and atrophy throughout the body due to the degeneration of the upper and lower motor neurons. Patients may experience difficulties in swallowing and general weakness.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Guillain-Barre Syndrome is a rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves, leading to muscle weakness and sometimes paralysis. Symptoms can also include difficulty with eye muscles and vision, difficulty swallowing, speaking, or chewing.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: A transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. A TIA usually lasts only a few minutes and doesn't cause permanent damage. Symptoms mimic those of a stroke and can include paralysis or weakness, and difficulty speaking or swallowing.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraine with aura is a type of migraine that involves visual disturbances and other neurological symptoms (the 'aura') before the headache itself begins. Symptoms can include visual phenomena, such as seeing various shapes, bright spots or flashes of light (scintillations), which can be accompanied by muscle weakness.

diagnoses.name: Esophageal Cancer
diagnoses.description: Esophageal cancer occurs in the esophagus and is characterized by difficulty swallowing (dysphagia) as an early symptom. As the cancer grows, symptoms may include pain, weight loss, hoarseness, and worsening dysphagia.

diagnoses.name: Parkinson's Disease
diagnoses.description: Parkinson's disease is a progressive nervous system disorder that affects movement. Symptoms start gradually, sometimes starting with a barely noticeable tremor in just one hand. Symptoms often also include stiffness or slowing of movement. Dysphagia can occur in advanced stages.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms such as aphasia, weakness, and headache.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a minibar stroke, TIA presents similar to a stroke with sudden aphasia, weakness, or headache but usually resolves within minutes to hours without permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A growth of abnormal cells in the brain which can cause pressure symptoms like headache, weakness, and changes in speech or aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that can involve temporary vision or sensory disturbances followed by a severe headache, sometimes accompanied by weakness or difficulty speaking.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease affecting the brain and spinal cord, leading to symptoms like weakness, difficulty speaking, and headaches among others.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known collectively as the meninges, causing severe headache, aphasia, and weakness in severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain, often due to infection, can cause headache, problems with speech, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A collection of pus that develops in the brain due to infection, capable of producing symptoms such as aphasia, weakness, and severe headaches.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain. Some forms can present with aphasia or postictal weakness.

diagnoses.name: Hemorrhagic Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when a weakened blood vessel ruptures and bleeds into the surrounding brain, causing symptoms like headache, weakness, and sometimes problems with speech or understanding.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include sudden weakness, difficulty speaking or understanding speech, and headache.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraines with aura are a type of migraine that involves nerve-related symptoms (aura) before the actual migraine attack. These symptoms can include visual disturbances, speech difficulties, and sensory changes followed by a severe headache often accompanied by sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA is a brief period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke, such as weakness and difficulty speaking. Unlike a stroke, the symptoms of a TIA usually last less than an hour and do not leave lasting damage.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor is a mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Depending on the location, it can cause headaches, speech difficulties, weakness, and various other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: MS is a disease of the central nervous system that disrupts the flow of information within the brain and between the brain and body. Symptoms can include fatigue, difficulty speaking (dysarthria), weakness, and more.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: Also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, ALS affects nerve cells in the brain and the spinal cord, leading to muscle weakness, difficulty speaking (dysarthria), and eventually severe motor impairments.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Encephalitis is inflammation of the brain caused by an infection or an autoimmune response. Common symptoms include headache, weakness, confusion, and difficulties with speech.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A brain abscess is a collection of pus that develops in response to an infection or trauma. Symptoms can mimic those of a stroke or brain tumor, including headaches, speech difficulties, and weakness or paralysis of one side of the body.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is an inflammation of the fluid and membranes (meninges) surrounding the brain and spinal cord. Symptoms can include headache, fever, stiffness of the neck, and in severe cases, difficulty speaking and neurological deficits.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: Epilepsy is a central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Some types of epilepsy can also cause difficulty speaking or understanding language before or after seizures.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include sudden weakness, numbness, difficulty speaking, headache, and vision problems.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A migraine with aura is a severe headache that's preceded or accompanied by sensory disturbances called aura. These disturbances can include flashes of light, blind spots, and other vision changes or tingling in your hand or face.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). It attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers and causes communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body. Symptoms include numbness, weakness, balance issues, and speech disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a ministroke, a transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a brief, temporary disturbance of blood supply to part of the brain, spinal cord, or retina, causing stroke-like symptoms but without lasting damage.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Brain tumors can be cancerous or noncancerous. They can cause symptoms by directly pressing on the surrounding brain or by causing a buildup of fluid and swelling. Symptoms may include headaches, weakness, numbness, difficulty speaking, and vision problems.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is an inflammation of the fluid and membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord. The swelling from meningitis typically triggers symptoms such as headache, fever, and a stiff neck.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A brain abscess is a collection of pus, immune cells, and other material in the brain, usually from a bacterial or fungal infection. Symptoms may include headache, fever, weakness on one side of the body, speech difficulties, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Guillain-Barré syndrome is a rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing your whole body.

diagnoses.name: Brain Aneurysm
diagnoses.description: A brain aneurysm is a bulge or ballooning in a blood vessel in the brain. It often looks like a berry hanging on a stem. A brain aneurysm can leak or rupture, causing bleeding into the brain (hemorrhagic stroke). Symptoms can include a sudden severe headache, weakness, numbness, vision problems, and confusion.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: Epilepsy is a central nervous system (neurological) disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Symptoms can vary widely.

diagnoses: Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with ITP)
Rickettsial Diseases (including Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever)
Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
